More Notes: The increase in climate vulnerability index (ND-GAIN) results in a 27% rise in the 90th quantile of the 2-year spread. The same increase results in only a 7% rise in the 10th quantile of the 2-year and 1-year spreads.

The increase in climate vulnerability index (ND-GAIN) results in a 14% rise in the 90th quantile of the 1-year spread. The same increase results in only a 7% rise in the 10th quantile of the 2-year and 1-year spreads.
For longer maturities (5-year and 10-year), the increase in climate vulnerability index impacts only the 10th percentile, resulting in an approximately 13-14% increase.

Increased vulnerability to climate change contributes to higher spreads across all maturities. Higher debt-to-GDP ratio, and inflation also contribute to higher spreads. This is a qualitative result but scaled to 0.01 for the sake of quantification, to represent 'positive' increase

Vulnerability to climate change increases spreads, especially for high-risk countries with short-term debt. This is a qualitative result but scaled to 0.01 for the sake of quantification, to represent 'positive' increase

Readiness to adapt can mitigate this (increase in borrowing costs). This is a qualitative result but scaled to -0.01 for the sake of quantification, to represent 'negative' increase (decrease in borrowing costs)
The magnitude of the common factor representing market shocks is relatively small, impacting borrowing costs (sovereign risk).
The common factor impacts borrowing costs across all maturities within certain quantiles of spreads.

Sovereign spreads increase due to climate change vulnerability and inflation, especially for short maturities and specific quantiles. Described as a 'positive effect' on spreads, but with no concrete value reported, I have defaulted to zero.
Impact of inflation on 1-year spreads, moving from the 90th to the 10th quantile.
Impact of inflation on 2-year spreads, moving from the 90th to the 10th quantile.
Impact of inflation on 10-year spreads, moving from the 90th to the 10th quantile.

The effect associated with the debt-to-GDP ratio, frequently emphasized in the literature, is generally non-significant at short maturities in most of our specifications. When significant, the effect is relatively modest, ranging between 8 and 11 percent for the median and the 90th quantile of the 2-year spread.

Positive relationship between vulnerability and sovereign risk, particularly pronounced at highest quantiles of spreads.  Value and high value are illustrative, based on 'comparable to inflation effect' and 'pronounced at highest quantiles', respectively.

Impact is negative when disaster exposure/deaths is significant. The effects are small, and below 4 percent in absolute terms, with one notable exception.
Positive impact on 2-year spreads for the second cluster of countries, the second category of disasters and the 90th percentile.
Downgrades are anticipated by 2030 due to climate change, based on Klusak et al. (2023) using machine learning to simulate prospective scenarios of sovereign debt ratings.
Noteworthy increases in funding costs posing a concern for companies and countries most vulnerable to climate change. Based on Klusak et al. (2023).
The effect of natural disasters on sovereign spreads is very small or insignificant once one controls for traditional determinants of sovereign risk.
